title: Move starting counter to where it should be.
body:
Fixes two problems:
1. starting container counter incorrectly incremented when action gets a stem cell container; this should not be the case and over accounts for active containers. Moved the counter into the docker serializer where it will correctly account for the new container. The counter is inside the synchronized region rather than outside may allow more actions to try and make progress but will these will serialize on the docker lock anyway.
2. the activation counting had a race and was off by ~1 (approximately because the initialization was wrong and how many counters are created depends on the number of concurrent activations for a specific user).

title: native binaries with dockerskeleton
body:
Allow docker skeleton to be initialized by arbitrary gzipper tar ball as long as it is executable within the openwhisk/dockerskeleton container. This has a few advantages: 1. don't need to pull image from dockerhub (unpacking a tar ball should be faster but I did not measure it yet), 2. `exec` can be precompiled making cold start faster (same comment re measuring), 3. could keep the container image small (don't need to install gcc, swiftc, etc. to compile various flavors of native executables). Of course, the executable must be statically linked if it has library dependencies. For more complex requirements, one may still use the more general docker actions. As such, this is NOT a replacement for general docker actions.

As a general optimization, the dockerskeleton images should be pushed to the invoker anyway to save fetching layers for blackbox actions that use the openwhisk docker action sdk.

In anticipation of action attachments, this is modeled after the java jars.

Here's an example of how to use it:

```
on host:
# cd /Users/Shared
# docker run -v /Users/Shared/:/workspace -it dockerskeleton bash

now inside container
# cd /workspace
# apk add --no-cache bzip2-dev gcc libc-dev
# echo '#include <stdio.h>
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) { printf("hello blackbox\n"); printf("%s\n", argv[1]); }' > bb.c
# gcc -o exec -static bb.c
# tar zcf bb.tgz exec

exit container to return to host /Users/Shared
# wsk action create bb openwhisk/dockerskeleton --docker --lib bb.tgz
ok: created action bb
# wsk action invoke bb --blocking --result -p msg hello
{
    "msg": "hello"
}
```

One caveat is that we exempt blackbox actions from log sentinel filtering but this is a case where we should filter the sentinel out. In fact this will be the case for any blackbox action that uses the docker action sdk. Otherwise the logs will look like this:

```
"logs": [
        "2016-08-31T03:45:48.44970514Z  stderr: XXX_THE_END_OF_A_WHISK_ACTIVATION_XXX",
        "2016-08-31T03:45:48.449739089Z stdout: hello blackbox",
        "2016-08-31T03:45:48.449742919Z stdout: XXX_THE_END_OF_A_WHISK_ACTIVATION_XXX"
]
```

It's also worth noting that in general this extends the `initialization` support to black box actions - while currently on initialization, the container does not receive any data, it will now receive whatever payload is attached to the action via `--lib`.

FYI @psuter, @paulcastro.

labels.name: pgapproved
labels.description: Pipeline has approved this change.

title: All blocking invokes convert to non-blocking after 60 seconds
body:
Regardless of action timeout, controller converts blocking requests to non-blocking after min(60 seconds, action timeout). The API responds with the activation id and 202. Nginx conf is adjusted accordingly (70 seconds = 60 + 10 seconds to allow controller to terminate connection vs nginx).

Related to #1140.

title: Remove sleeps
body:
Remove unnecessary sleeps in invoker:
- a 3s sleep before calling /init for black box containers is not necessary since the HTTP call will retry.
- slack sleeps after init also not necessary since if container respond to inits, it's ready to run.
- sleep during nio channel draining should not be necessary.

And adds tests using blackbox actions for containers that misbehave to confirm they will timeout with expected exception. Three cases are tested:
1. blackbox that doesn't implement a proper proxy (doesn't run a proxy at all)
2. blackbox that doesn't respond to init (implements /init but does not respond)
3. blackbox that doesn't respond to run (implements /run but does not respond)

remote entitlement flows.

title: Supercedes 1071 - lifts active ack processing to avoid race
body:
Lift listener for active ack responses in action activations before the post to loadbalancer - this avoids a race where the response comes back before the listener becomes active. Use activation id generator to allow testing of blocking invokes. Adds tests for active path (previously missing). Refactors the logic for active ack processing.

Also in this pull request:
1. fix reading from consul in whisk config: allow read from consul to fail if consul is not responsive as long as required properties are set.
2. convert all blocking invokes to non-blocking after 60 seconds (regardless of the action timeout limit).

Thanks to @markusthoemmes and @cbickel for feedback.

Replaces #1071.
Fixes #1067.

title: Attached jars
body:
Working implementation of attachments for jars in Java actions. For review only at this point to discuss design etc. I'm only moderately satisfied for instance with my attempt at separating attachment API methods in `AttachmentStore`, for instance (how long can we really pretend that `ArtifactStore` is db-agnostic?).

It's likely that supporting attachments for other kinds of actions will lead to at least some refactoring to isolate common patterns. The `Attachment[T]` class is already an example of that.

Note that this PR is fully backwards compatible: the jar is always retrieved to build the Java action entity. As a consequence, it does not e.g. involve streaming beyond the DB <-> entity interactions.

title: update slack.post to support token-based auth
body:
This PR updates slack.post to support slack's oauth token style of authentication. If `params.token` is defined, the post assumes it is using token style authentication.

The only minor complexity here lies in the format of the body that slack expects, combined with some limitations of the formData npm that the request npm uses. The (preexisting) webhook-style API expects the formData to have the form `{ payload: body }`, whereas the slack API expects it to be of the form `body`, i.e. no payload wrapper. On top of this, the formData npm cannot tolerate nested objects -- this is why the slack.post code has always called `JSON.stringify` on the body. This is not needed (and causes harm) for the slack API-style of invocation.

Next, I removed the icon_emoji from the body if it is not defined by params. formData also barfs on `undefined`. This required updating the test to remove the expectation of seeing icon_emoji in the output.

The last change to the post.js code: I pulled the `console.log` calls so that they'd only execute in the webhook code path, in order to avoid leaking an unredacted auth token to the logs.

I also updated the docs/catalog.md to describe the new token-based auth support.

Finally, I updated installSlack  to add description and doclink fields. Here, I hoisted the bindTime parameters from the action annotation to the level of a package annotation. This has been a long-standing issue with the slack metadata that forced the Bluemix UI code to have some hacks: i.e. when prompting the user for a package binding, we had to hackishly look at the action annotations, even though the user had requested to make a package binding -- an operation independent of any action.

closes #1091 
PG1 229 [clean]

title: One proxy for swift(3), python and docker actions
body:
Adds "action proxy" a new base image for actions including swift and "black box" using a common proxy server coded in python and using flask. The proxy implements the required init and run routes. The container include a sample shell script making it useful as a stand alone example action. It also allows arbitrary shell scripts (python, perl, bash, etc.) to run by initializing the internal action code on init. The run methods always prints the required sentinels, making actions that inherit from this proxy compliant with the invoker's expectations for extracting user log streams.

Elaborates bash example with comments and showing logging as well as receiving action input.
Rebase swift/3 and python to use canonical image (which also becomes the docker skeleton).
Add Python actions to set of sentinelled actions for which the invoker will wait for marker while fetching logs.

Fixes #1012.
Fixes #691.
Fixes #661.
Fixes #518.
Fixed #982.

@psuter @ioana-blue @bjustin-ibm @perryibm for your review. The commits are grouped and are progressive, so that it's easier to process.

title: Annotations Must be Parsed as Raw JSON
body:
Annotations Must be Parsed as Raw JSON

parameter/annotation `key` input value is a string.  It will be converted into a JSON string doing
`\` and `"` escaping.  If it's not a valid JSON string after that, an error is returned.

parameter/annotation `value` input value is expected to be valid JSON.  If it is not valid JSON,
and it is NOT surrounded by either {} or [], it will be surrounded with double quotes making it a JSON
string.  In all cases, if the final value is still not valid JSON, an error is returned.

Replaces PR #953 
Fixes #952 
Fixes #717 
Fixes #718
